title: Nearly a million 16-24 year-olds not working or in education
partialText: People at the start of their careers are particularly affected by the UK's weak job market.

title: World Economic Forum boss quits after review of Epstein links
partialText: Brende acknowledged communications with Epstein but said he was "completely unaware" of his past criminal activity.

title: Royal Mail bosses to be called to Parliament over letter delivery failures
partialText: It comes after hundreds of people contacted BBC Your Voice to express frustration over late deliveries.

title: Instagram to alert parents if teens search for self-harm and suicide content
partialText: Safety campaigners say Meta is "passing the buck" with its new feature for parents using Instagram's teen supervision tools.

title: Faisal Islam: Is the UK economy really turning a corner?
partialText: The Chancellor is trying to use this moment as a launching pad for a wider attempt to gee up consumer and business confidence.

title: The family-owned soda firm that still uses returnable glass bottles
partialText: Soft drinks company Twig's Beverage has a loyal following for its old-fashioned approach.

title: Ocado to axe 1,000 jobs in cost-cutting drive
partialText: The technology and online grocery group is cutting about 5% of its global workforce, with two-thirds of the losses in the UK.

title: Chip giant Nvidia defies AI concerns with record $215bn revenue
partialText: Demand for Nvidia chips rose even as the company sets out to create AI products of its own.

title: Aldi shop staff to receive two pay rises this year
partialText: The German budget supermarket is a growing competitor among British supermarkets.

title: MrBeast video editor fined over insider trading
partialText: A former California governor candidate was also disciplined as the prediction market Kalshi cracks down.

title: New travel rules for UK visitors kick in - how are you affected?
partialText: From 25 February, a new system will come into force which will affect many people, including British dual nationals.

title: Why Asian firms are not cheering Trump tariff ruling
partialText: The US Supreme Court's decision to block a pillar of US trade policy has caused yet more uncertainty.

title: Canada's finance minister says US is unlikely to lift tariffs
partialText: The comments come after US President Donald Trump said he wants global tariffs to replace income taxes as America's main revenue source.

title: Household energy bills to fall in April after charges shake-up
partialText: Changes announced in the Budget mean all energy bills will see some kind of reduction, but it will vary.

title: John Lewis pulls out of housebuilding business
partialText: The retailer began expanding into housebuilding in 2020 but it is scrapping those plans to focus on retail instead.

title: Tesco to cut 180 jobs within its head office
partialText: Chief executive Ken Murphy says Tesco must be “efficient and agile” to compete.

title: Aston Martin cuts 20% of workforce as losses widen
partialText: About 600 jobs will go at the luxury car maker, which in part blames US tariffs for its troubles.

title: Gucci criticised for 'AI slop' images ahead of major fashion show
partialText: Users of social media - where the marketing campaign has been launched - say it is out of keeping with Gucci's reputation for luxury.

title: Not even potholes will hold up self-driving cars, UK firm predicts
partialText: Wayve says it's confident all cars will one day be autonomous, as it announced more than a £1bn in additional investment.

title: Shein's elusive boss hails Chinese roots in rare public appearance
partialText: His speech follows years of the firm focusing away from China as it moved its headquarters to Singapore.

title: Discord delays age verification plans after user outcry
partialText: Users were unhappy about plans for age verification to require facial or ID scans.

title: Is TikTok the new frontier for fashion reinvention?
partialText: How a young designer got brought on to help redesign a legacy sports brand following a TikTok post.

title: Paramount boosts Warner Bros offer to rival Netflix in takeover bid
partialText: Warner Bros says the latest proposal could convince it to abandon the deal it struck with Netflix.

title: US threatens Anthropic with deadline in dispute on AI safeguards
partialText: The AI developer laid out red lines on military use of its products, a source said.

title: Apple says some Mac Mini production will move to the US
partialText: The technology giant had pledged to increase investment in the US by $600bn, under pressure from Trump.

title: Google apologises for Baftas alert to 'see more' on racial slur
partialText: Google said the news alert was an error that should not have happened.

title: House prices in Wales rise faster than UK average - see how your area compares
partialText: Some areas have seen average house prices increase by 7% in the past year, according to ONS data.

title: Orbital space race heats up in Arctic north
partialText: Europe lags far behind the US and China in orbital space launches, but new facilities are opening up.

title: Are you cut out for living and working in Antarctica?
partialText: Jobs are available on the icy continent for chefs, plumbers, carpenters and even hairdressers.

title: How do you modernise mango farming?
partialText: India's mango farmers are being urged to innovate as climate change makes cultivation "unpredictable".

title: The two farms in Senegal that supply many of the UK's vegetables
partialText: During winter in Britain fresh produce is sent by cargo ship from the West African nation every week.

title: Reddit's human content wins amid the AI flood
partialText: Reddit says its human contributors are valued amid an internet awash with AI-generated content.

title: Trump eyes Venezuela visit – but obstacles to his oil plan remain
partialText: The US president wants American energy firms to start extracting the crude but they are reluctant.

title: Get a grip: Robotics firms struggle to develop hands
partialText: Developing a durable and affordable hand is one of the biggest challenges in robotics.

title: Who is billionaire Sir Jim Ratcliffe and how did he make his money?
partialText: The industrialist and Manchester United co-owner has apologised over comments he made about immigration.

title: The US economy is growing - so where are all the jobs?
partialText: As hiring rates and job openings drop, some worry a tough job market could be here to stay.

title: The Dutch love four-day working weeks, but are they sustainable?
partialText: The Netherlands has the lowest working hours in Europe, but some say it is harming its economy.

title: Why food fraud persists, even with improving tech
partialText: Even with sophisticated technology it is still difficult to detect fake foods.

title: Netflix and Paramount are battling for Warner Bros. Who is likely to win?
partialText: What to know about the two firms' blockbuster battle to control Warner Bros Discovery.

title: How £50m 'fish disco' could save farmland
partialText: Innovative tech scares fish away from nuclear cooling pipes.

title: Pressure to make budgets add up as Holyrood election looms
partialText: Parties hoping to form at least part of a government will want to show how they will pay for their vote-winning promises

title: Rescue centre at 'breaking point' over £40k bills
partialText: The Ark Wildlife Park is home to exotic animals such as crocodiles, monkeys and wildcats.

title: Food banks 'essential' for new generation of students
partialText: Queen's University Belfast says there were more than 10,500 visits by students to its food bank in the students' union.

partialText: Changes announced in the Budget mean all energy bills will see some kind of reduction, but it will vary.

title: The real impact of roadworks on the country - and why they're set to get worse
partialText: There is a fine balance between the benefits of improved infrastructure, versus the cost of disruption. Does the country have it right?

title: Why the railways often seem to be in such chaos over Christmas
partialText: Parts of Britain’s rail network will close for engineering work over the festive period - but is that the right time to do it?

title: Budget 2025: What's the best and worst that could happen for Labour?
partialText: Three days in, after a tax U-turn and partial climbdown on workers' rights, Laura Kuenssberg looks at what impact Budget week might have.

title: Has Britain's budget watchdog become too all-powerful?
partialText: Ahead of this week's Budget, some have accused the Office for Budget Responsibility of being a "straitjacket on growth"

title: The curious case of why Poundland is struggling during a cost-of-living crisis
partialText: Why - in an age where so many of us are feeling the financial pinch - are some budget shops on UK high streets having such a tough time?

partialText: Typical household energy bills will fall by 7% in April, regulator Ofgem has announced, following a shake-up in charges by the government.

title: When the retail staff can't help you
